messages.content: <<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "energyLevel" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Energy level describes how active a dog typically is. High-energy dogs need sustained daily exercise and mental work and stimulation; low-energy dogs are content with shorter outings and calm time at home. Choose a level you can consistently provide so the dog thrives long-term.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "trainability" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Trainability reflects how readily a dog learns and responds to guidance. Highly trainable breeds enjoy structured practice and clear feedback; independent breeds can learn too, but need patience and consistency. Match your time and interest in training to the breed.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "droolingLevel" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Drooling level indicates how much saliva a breed typically produces. Some dogs drool mainly after drinking or exercise; others drool throughout the day due to lip and jowl structure. If you value clean fabrics, pick lower drooling or plan for towels and frequent wipe-downs.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "opennessToStrangers" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Openness to strangers is how friendly a dog tends to be with unfamiliar people. High openness suits social environments but may reduce watchdog behavior; lower openness can mean aloof or cautious, requiring careful socialization. Match this to your home’s traffic, lifestyle and expectations.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "protectiveNature" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Protective nature is a dog’s tendency to guard home and family. It can be a positive trait with training and boundaries and depending on your goals as a dog owner, but unmanaged protection may lead to reactivity. Pick appropriately for your neighborhood, visitors, and your ability to provide structure.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "groomingFrequency" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Grooming frequency covers brushing, bathing, and trims a breed typically needs. Curly or long coats need regular upkeep to prevent mats; smooth coats need less but still shed. Budget time and cost for tools or professional grooming to keep skin and coat healthy.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "affectionateWithFamily" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

This trait reflects how readily a breed seeks closeness with household members. Some dogs bond deeply with one person; others are broadly cuddly. Consider your home’s routines and how much daily contact you can provide. Even affectionate breeds need rest and consent—teach calm greetings and respect for boundaries.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "goodWithYoungChildren" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

This signals how tolerant and patient a breed tends to be with small children. A higher score helps in busy homes but still requires supervision, respectful handling, and safe zones for the dog. If you have or expect young kids, prioritize calmer, patient breeds and practice structured interactions.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "goodWithOtherDogs" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

This reflects a breed’s typical ease with other dogs. Friendly breeds still need early socialization; more selective breeds can coexist with careful management. If you already have a dog or visit dog spaces often, weigh this trait heavily and introduce slowly on neutral ground.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "playfulnessLevel" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Playfulness describes how eager a breed is to engage in games beyond puppyhood. High playfulness can be great for active households; lower playfulness suits calmer homes. Match this to how you spend downtime—tug and fetch fans versus couch companions.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "adaptabilityLevel" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Adaptability is how well a dog tolerates changes in routine, environment, sounds, and people. Highly adaptable breeds handle travel and schedule shifts more easily. If your life is variable, consider higher adaptability; if your home is quiet and predictable, a lower-adaptability breed can still thrive.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "livingEnvironment" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Living environment covers your setting (e.g., urban, suburban, rural) and space. Some breeds cope well with apartments if their exercise and enrichment needs are met; others benefit from larger yards or access to fields. Choose a breed whose daily needs fit your space and neighborhood norms.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "coatType" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Coat type refers to hair structure (e.g., smooth, double, curly, wire). It affects grooming effort, shedding, and sometimes climate tolerance. Curly and wire coats need regular maintenance to avoid mats; double coats shed seasonally and shouldn’t be shaved. Choose a coat you can reliably care for.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "coatLength" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Coat length (short, medium, long) changes grooming time and how much debris a dog carries indoors. Long coats can mat without routine brushing; short coats still shed and benefit from regular care. Pick a length that fits your time and budget for maintenance.
<<SYSTEM>>
Explain the dog trait "sizeCategory" for breed selection. Keep it short and practical.

Size (small, medium, large) influences space needs, handling strength, and cost (food, equipment, vet care). Large breeds may need sturdier housing and training for safe leash manners; small dogs still need enrichment and confidence building. Choose a size that fits your home and daily routines.
